Hirschhorn FoundationDavid and Barbara MarguliesThe Nash Family FoundationHarris RosenDavid and Sylvia SteinerRuth TaubmanOriginal publication dataAUTHORTITLEIMPRINTDESCRIPTSUBJECTadd'l NAMEAroesti, Jacob.Bitol]ski Jevreji / Jacob Aroesti, Milos Konstantinov, Dusko Konstantinov.[Belgrade : o. fg., 1959]5,16, 865Jews -- Macedonia — Bitola — HistoryHolocaust, Jewish (1939-1945) — Macedonia — Bitola.Bitola (Macedonia) — Ethnic relations.Konstantinov, Milos.Konstantinov, Dusko.THIS BOOK MEETS A.N.S.I. STANDARDS FORPAPER PERMANENCE AND LIBRARY BINDING.PRINTED IN THE U.S.A.ForewordThis Yizkor book of the Sephardic Jews of Bitola, Yugoslavia, is surely the most obscureHolocaust memorial book ever produced. Until now, it has not been found in any Yizkor bookcoUection in the United States. There are no mentions of it in bibliographies of such books, and ithas even eluded the notice of the eminent Jewish librarian Zachary Baker, whose list of memorialvolumes is the standard in the field. The bibliographic record at the Yad Vashem archives, whichholds the only known manuscript copy of the book, also offers no clue as to its identity. The entrydoes not identify it as a Yizkor book. Instead, it is described as a History of the Jewish Communityof Bitola {Toldot hehilatyehudit Bitola). The only explicit mention of the book is found in theobscure 1971 volume A Town Called Monastir^ which is a portrait of the Bitola Jews that caUs thetown by its Ottoman Turkish name (and the one commonly used by its Jews). But even that bookdoes not give the Yizkor book’s title, nor does it teU where it could be found. This book, whichmemorializes more than 3,000 Jews, was itself for years lost and forgotten.OriginsAt the end of World War II, Jacob Aroesti was one of the few Bitola Jews to survive theHolocaust. The city’s Spanish-speahing Sephardim, descendants of the Jews who had settled in thetown shortly after their expulsion from Spain in 1492, were deported to Treblinka in the spring of1943. The most reliable account of the community’s destruction, The Jews in Macedonia Duringthe Second World War, determined that the Nazis murdered 3,276 Bitola Jews, which was virtuaUy100 per cent of the community. Only a few dozen people were able to evade deportation andescape into Bitola’s surrounding mountains, where some survived as Partisan fighters. About 60Jews returned to Bitola after the war only to find that aU of the city’s Jewish institutions had beendestroyed. Most of the returning Jews soon left.Jacob Aroesti decided to stay. Before the war, Aroesti had been an official of the Bitola Jewishcommunity, and he appears to have overseen charitable programs the community maintained toaUeviate poverty. According to ZamUa Kolonomos, a Bitola Jew and historian who today lives inthe neighboring city of Skopje, before the war Aroesti had dealings with nearly everyone in theJewish community and was known for his exceUent memory. After the war, and untU his death in1960, Aroesti continued his work on behalf of the Bitola Jews. He was employed by the BitolaArchives to establish a record group caUed “The Jews in Bitola, 1860 - 1960.”To produce this book, Aroesti joined forces with two Macedonian brothers and researchers,MUos and Dusko Konstantinov. Aroesti and the Konstantinovs found their sources in pre-warJewish community records, as weU as a register of the adult Jewish population that was compUedin 1942 in preparation for the Jews’ deportation. Using those documents, the three men in 1959produced this book, entitled Bitoljshi Jevreji (Bitolj’s Jews). Its 865 pages include a 57-pageintroduction and 808 pages of biographical entries on 3,762 Bitola Jews, which was the numberthe writers believed had been kiUed in the Holocaust. It is written in Serbo-Croatian, with the firsthalf in the CyriUic alphabet and the remainder written in the Latin alphabet.The book was never published. Only two typed copies of it were ever produced.RediscoveryIn 1997, when I Kegan researching my history of the Bitola-Monastir Jews, I found mention ofthis memorial volume in A Town Called Monastir. In my determination to find it, I contacted the- 1 -Bitola Archives and the Jewish Federation of Belgrade, Yugoslavia. The latter was able to confirmthat such a book did exist, but had become lost. Years before, one copy had been sold to someonein the United States. No record of the sale was kept. The second copy, according to the lastsurviving author, Dusko Konstantinov, was deposited with the Belgrade Jewish Community. ButBelgrade did not have it. My search quickly came to a dead end.By October 2000,1 was close to completing my research when I received a response to aninquiry I had submitted to the Yad Vashem archives. It was a list of manuscript items regardingthe Bitola Jews. The History of the Jewish Community of Bitola had been highlighted by thearchivist, who wrote next to it in the margin, “988 pages.” The girth caught my eye. Yizkor bookscommonly tip the scales at close to 900 pages. I soon confirmed that it was the lost Yizkor book.Mute TestimonyIn many ways, this Yizkor book is similar to the many hundreds of others that commemoratethe communities destroyed in the Holocaust. Like all memorial books, the overwhelmingmajority of its pages are devoted to preserving the names of the dead. Here, each family unit isgiven an individually numbered subhead, under which is an entry for each member of the family.Biographical details almost always include date and place of birth, and sometimes much more.For example, the entry for Mordo Nahmias, on page 573, takes up three-quarters of a page andmentions the years he lived Belgrade, his return to Bitola, and his membership in YugosIavia’scommunist party..The book’s introduction also resembles what is found in other Yizkor books. There is a historyof the community, which in this Sephardic case includes the story of the Golden Ageof Spain and its flourishing Jewish life, Spain’s expulsion of the Jews, and their arrival in theOttoman Empire, which ruled much of southeastern Europe, including Bitola. There is alsoinformation about prominent rabbis of the community, 20^^ century charitable organizations, anda proud assertion that when the false messiah Sabbetai Zevi caused many century OttomanJews to believe that the age of redemption had arrived, the Jews of Bitola refused to swerve awayfrom normative Jewish practice.But despite these similarities, this book is unusual in a disturbing way. What is most striking isthe complete absence of any Jewish symbols, Hebrew lettering, or Jewish language. There is noStar of David, no Hebrew, and no Judeo-Spanish, which was the native language of the Bitola Jews.It is a book cut off from its past and its community. The Serbo-Croatian language and Cyrillicalphabet made it unintelligible to the 3,000 Bitola-Monastir Jews who had emigrated to the UnitedStates in the early 20^^ century, when the city was under Ottoman rule. At that time, the Jewsspoke Judeo-Spanish at home, learned French at the Alliance Israélite Universelle schools, andspoke Greek in the marketplace. The Bitola Jews who emigrated to Israel in the 1930s, when thecity was under Yugoslav rule, had indeed received their early schooling in Serbo-Croat. But by1959, Hebrew would have been a better way to reach out to them.Instead, the choice of Serbo-Croatian seems to indicate a despair in finding an audience. It is abook that expects no readers. It seems less a literate communication than a mute sign, a tombstone for thousands.—Mark CohenMark Cohen is the author of Last Century of a Sephardic Community: The Jews of Monastir, 1839-1943.- 2 -03-038126ApoecTH da.KoBKoHCT3jmiI0B JLmKOKohcTajnnnoh Mmoui1959 ,3 M TO A dU5 il 0 1,1 C UAPQBGTE JÍEOBEOHCTAHTHHDB ;ri3E0EOHCTAHTHHDB mmMB2 TO;&CKE JBBPB JHB H S 0 ib19 5 9G A Jí P IT A J1, jMecfo npeflroBOpa.
